SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Feeling out of sorts, fatigue, and lightheadedness.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue and lightheadedness. Denies fever or chills.
Cardiovascular: Reports feeling bloated occasionally. Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during exertion and a slight cough. Denies difficulty breathing at rest.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension.

VITALS

Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation all within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters. 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Respiratory: Fine crackles at lung bases bilaterally.
Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS
Imaging AND LAB RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: Retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
- Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once daily. Weigh daily and report weight gain or shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure currently well-managed.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report elevated readings through the patient portal.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after test results are received or sooner if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Difficulty urinating.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports difficulty urinating for the past six months, with a weak stream and occasional incomplete bladder emptying. Patient wakes up three to four times a night to urinate.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Coronary artery disease with stent placement in 2018, diabetes.

MEDICATIONS

Metformin 1000 mg twice a day, Lipitor 40 mg a day, aspirin, and metoprolol.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies constipation, reports recent diarrhea episode.
Genitourinary: Difficulty urinating, denies burning sensation or urinary retention.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Slight 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard at the left base.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Gastrointestinal: Abdomen nontender and nondistended, no masses or rebound guarding.
Rectal: Enlarged prostate appreciated, no masses.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Difficulty urinating:
   - Order routine labs including PSA, urinalysis, and urine culture.
   - Start Flomax 0.4 mg once at night.
   - Refer to urologist for further evaluation.

2. Coronary artery disease:
   - Order echocardiogram and lipid panel.
   - Continue Lipitor 40 mg a day, aspirin, and metoprolol.

3. Diabetes:
   - Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day.
   - Order hemoglobin A1c.

FOLLOW-UP

Patient to follow up in 3 to 4 weeks and advised to call or message in the patient portal if any concerns arise.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Lower back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history of diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He presents with lower back pain after lifting heavy boxes. The pain started on Saturday and has persisted since then. He reports a popping sound during the incident and had to lie down for an hour to relieve the pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes type 2, hypertension, osteoarthritis.

MEDICATIONS

Metformin, Lisinopril, Tylenol, Ibuprofen.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Neurological: Reports tingling in toes on the right foot, which resolved on Sunday.

VITALS

BP: Elevated in the office.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS
Imaging

Back X-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fracture present.

LABS

Hemoglobin A1c: 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lumbar strain: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.
2. Diabetes: Increase Metformin to 1000 mg twice a day, repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
3. Hypertension: Increase Lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.
4. Osteoarthritis: Continue monitoring knee, no further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed and continue monitoring blood pressure at home.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam for a 62-year-old male with a past medical history of depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports a relatively stable mood with depression managed on Prozac. He has been experiencing some difficulty with hypertension control, particularly on weekends when he may forget to take his medication. He also reports shortness of breath with exertion during his daily 4-5 mile runs, particularly in humid conditions.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or night sweats.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath with exertion.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pounding during exercise.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
Psychiatric: Depression managed on Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 120/80 in the office today.
Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower extremity edema.
Head and Neck: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Patient reports stable mood and adherence to medication. Refill prescription as needed.
2. Prior lobectomy: No further workup needed. Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function. No need for follow-up with a surgeon.
3. Hypertension: Blood pressure well-controlled in the office today. Continue Norvasc as prescribed. Encourage patient to maintain medication adherence on weekends.
4. Systolic ejection murmur: Order an echocardiogram to further evaluate the murmur. Follow up with results through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right finger pain.

The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and injured her finger while going over moguls. The injury occurred four days ago (on Sunday). She has tried applying ice and taking ibuprofen for the pain, but it has not improved. The pain is worse with movement.

The patient also mentions a history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Right index finger: Tenderness over the distal phalanx and pain with flexion. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint.
• X-ray: No fractures identified, normal alignment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of right finger pain.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's history, physical exam, and normal x-ray findings suggest a contusion without fracture.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instructed the patient to use an aluminum foam splint and take 600 mg of Motrin every six hours for one week.
• Medical Treatment: Ordered aluminum foam splint and Motrin 600 mg every six hours for one week.

Follow-up: If the pain does not improve within a week, the patient is advised to call and return for further evaluation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents to the clinic today with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, and increased anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since the age of 13 and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

General: Fatigue, feverishness, chills.
Respiratory: Shortness of breath, wheezing.
Neurological: Headaches.
Psychiatric: Increased anxiety and depression.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hysterectomy in 1996.

MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily, over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient is alert and oriented.
Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed.
2. Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for better absorption.
3. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.
4. Referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.
5. If endoscopy and colonoscopy results are inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy.
2. Schedule appointment with hematologist Dr. Flores.
3. Follow bowel prep instructions for colonoscopy.
4. Call the clinic if there are any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bruce Ward, a 52-year-old male, presents to the clinic for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient has been experiencing worsening headaches over the past few months, with no prior history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. He has noticed bumping into door frames recently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Neurological: Reports worsening headaches, located behind the eyes, with a dull, nagging ache. Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological: Patient is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

The patient has been informed of the need for surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa. A transsphenoidal approach will be used for the surgery. The patient will be referred to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to monitor vision changes before and after surgery. The patient will also be scheduled for surgery with the assistance of the surgery scheduler, Deborah.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with the eye doctor and surgery scheduler as needed. The patient is advised to call if any questions arise.

CC:

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HPI:

Ms. Betty Hill, a 52-year-old female, presents today for an evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred three months ago. The chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. She reports that the pain was sharp and felt like a heart attack. The pain was worse with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. She went to the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. They suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. She has not had any recurrence of symptoms since the initial episode. She has a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal.

EXAM:

Examination of the abdomen shows mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities were noted.

ASSESSMENT:

1. GERD
2. Dyspepsia
3. Esophagitis
4. Musculoskeletal etiologies
5. Anxiety

It is suspected that the patient had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contributions from musculoskeletal etiologies.

PLAN:

Ms. Hill and I discussed the option of performing an EGD or upper endoscopy to evaluate her esophagus and stomach. However, given that her symptoms occurred three months ago and have not recurred, she elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. She will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Possible kidney issues related to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a former 34-week and 3-day-old twin. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills.
• Genitourinary: 8-10 wet diapers per day.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of possible kidney issues related to her chromosomal deletion syndrome. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature.

• Additional Testing: Kidney ultrasound to screen for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
• Follow-up: If the kidney ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up is needed. If there are abnormalities, the patient will be seen at the town center location to determine next steps and future follow-up.

Patient Agreements: The patient's guardian understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a female patient, presents with right wrist pain and swelling after falling while carrying a laundry basket down the stairs yesterday morning. She has not had any prior injuries to this arm. The pain is severe, rated 9/10, and has been partially relieved by ice, an ACE wrap, and ibuprofen. She reports mild tingling in her fingers but no numbness. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Head and Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
• Cardiovascular: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Bony crepitus appreciated.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated at 140/70 mmHg, likely due to pain.
• Heart Rate: Slightly elevated at 80 beats per minute.
• Temperature: Normal at 97.2°F.
• Respiratory Rate: Normal at 20 breaths per minute.

RESULTS

X-ray: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Diana presents with a right wrist Colles' fracture after a fall.

• Medical Treatment: Apply a brace to the right wrist.
• Surgical Treatment: Schedule surgery for fracture repair.
• Pain Management: Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain relief.
• Physical Therapy: Begin physical therapy a few weeks after surgery, with a frequency to be determined by the therapist.

Patient Education and Counseling: Informed the patient about the need for surgery and the expected recovery timeline, including wearing the brace for six weeks and attending physical therapy. Discussed the possibility of postponing her vacation in a month, depending on her progress and physical therapy recommendations. Encouraged her to return for a follow-up appointment in a month to assess her condition before the vacation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Wayne is a patient who presents today with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. He denies any specific injury but mentions that he has been active and working on renovating his basement. The patient reports difficulty reaching for objects, lifting objects, and reaching overhead due to pain. He has tried taking extra strength Tylenol every 6-8 hours, which provides some relief but does not completely alleviate the pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Left shoulder exam:
- Limited active and passive range of motion.
- Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus.
- No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints.
- Good hand grips.

Neurovascular exam of the left arm:
- Capillary refill less than 3 seconds.
- Sensation intact to light touch.

RESULTS

Left shoulder X-ray:
- No fractures identified.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

1. Order an MRI for the left shoulder to further evaluate the cause of pain.
2. Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks.
3. Continue taking Tylenol for pain management.
4. Consider a steroid injection if symptoms do not improve after physical therapy.
5. Schedule a follow-up visit after completing physical therapy.

INSTRUCTIONS

- Attend physical therapy sessions as recommended.
- Continue taking Tylenol for pain management.
- Schedule a follow-up visit after completing physical therapy.
- Call with any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient who presents with occasional left knee pain that occurs less than once a day. She reports that the pain comes and goes quickly and does not last long. The pain is located internally in the kneecap area. She denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any medication for the pain. The patient has an upcoming trip and is concerned about participating in line dancing due to her knee pain.

The patient also reports her blood pressure has been stable, and she has been taking her blood pressure medications regularly. Her fasting blood sugar has been running around 130.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left knee pain.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Endocrine: Endorses elevated fasting blood sugar.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, with a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam shows no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain.
   • Medical Reasoning: Likely arthritis in the left knee.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports stable blood pressure and adherence to medications.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.

3. Diabetes mellitus.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports elevated fasting blood sugar levels.
   • Additional Testing: Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel.
   • Medical Treatment: Assess the need for adjustments to metformin based on test results.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Bilateral knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient has been experiencing bilateral knee pain for about six months. The pain is described as a deep, achy pain located behind the kneecaps. The pain is worse when standing up from sitting or going up and down stairs.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient is an avid runner and works from home.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports bilateral knee pain. Denies knee swelling.
Skin: Denies redness.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 120/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 60 bpm
Respirations: 14

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological
- Orientation: Normal gait. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular, slower rate. No murmurs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. Normal gait. 3/5 abduction strength of the bilateral lower extremities. Otherwise, 5/5 strength in the bilateral lower extremities.
- Bilateral knees: No erythema, ecchymosis, or warmth. No effusion. Tender to palpation. Positive patellar grind test. Lachman, anterior and posterior drawer, and McMurray test are all negative bilaterally.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the bilateral knees shows no fractures or osteoarthritis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Patellofemoral pain syndrome, bilateral.
- Medical Reasoning: After reviewing her x-ray, previous MRI, and exam findings, her symptoms are consistent with patellofemoral pain syndrome.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of this condition in detail. I encouraged the patient to be conservative with her physical activity for now.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with over-the-counter NSAIDs for pain relief. We are going to refer her to physical therapy to help strengthen her lower extremities, increase mobility, and demonstrate proper running mechanics.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle is a 57-year-old male who presents for evaluation of low IgA level, which was discovered during a recent physical examination. He reports a history of frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger but is unsure if this is more than usual. He denies any history of frequent abdominal infections or diarrhea. He has no known family history of immune deficiencies. He was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Type 2 diabetes.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient owns a donut shop.
No history of smoking or alcohol use.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

MEDICATIONS

Metformin.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits, no fever.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Low IgA level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency: The patient presents with a low IgA level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live their entire lives without any significant issues. However, some may experience frequent respiratory, sinus, or abdominal infections. The patient does not report any significant history of infections. Additional blood work will be ordered to check other antibody levels. The patient is advised to watch for any infections that do not resolve or any changes in his abdominal tract. He should also inform healthcare providers of his IgA deficiency if he requires blood products in the future.

Right elbow pain.

He rates the pain as a 6/10 and states that it has been keeping him up at night and affecting his ability to perform certain activities. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. He has been engaging in pottery work during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

None reported.

Occupation: Unspecified.
Hobbies: Pottery.

Not discussed.

Ibuprofen.

Vitals: Within normal limits.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality observed.

Medial epicondylitis.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a middle-aged male who presents with chest pain and shortness of breath. He reports falling outside and experiencing chest pain but did not think much of it. He has a history of hypertension and has been taking Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc inconsistently. The patient admits to not watching his diet and consuming salty foods.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath.
• Sleep: No issues reported.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Blood pressure: 128/72
• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
• Lower extremities: Trace edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive Heart Failure (CHF).
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's CHF is likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Advised the patient to continue taking Bumex 2 mg once daily and to watch his diet, focusing on reducing salty food intake.
• Medical Treatment: Consult to nutrition for dietary advice. The patient should weigh himself daily and call if he gains 3 pounds in 2 days.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of hypertension and has been taking medications inconsistently.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to take Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg daily consistently.
• Medical Treatment: Ordered a renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.

Smoking Cessation.
• Patient reports mostly quitting smoking, with occasional lapses. Encouraged the patient to continue working on quitting completely.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sharp pain in the right side of the abdomen below the ribs for several days.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father had kidney stones.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Previous kidney stones, which the patient was able to pass.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Urinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen
- No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, and no peritoneal signs.
- Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen shows a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).
- Medical Treatment: Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, alternating with Tylenol. Provide a urine strainer to catch the stone for testing.
- Diagnostic Tests: Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
- Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 57-year-old male with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot. He also notes a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is hot to touch. The patient has been experiencing difficulty catching his breath and coughing for the past two days.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Diabetes.
Diabetic neuropathy.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking with his wife.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not reported.

MEDICATIONS

Antibiotics (currently on day 6 of a 10-day course).

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythema. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient presents with a nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer. A test to check blood supply for the wound will be ordered. Debridement will be performed in the office today, and a culture will be taken. Antibiotic therapy will be continued and potentially adjusted based on culture results. The patient will be closely monitored for the redness and swelling in his calf. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for seven days. The patient is advised to follow up with his endocrinologist to ensure proper diabetes management and maintain a hemoglobin A1c below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a patient who presents with a tick bite around his knee, which has been present for over a week. He reports that the area feels warm and is quite annoying. He denies any fever or chills but has been experiencing headaches and a general feeling of unwellness since the tick bite. He has a history of spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in his yard.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever or chills. Reports feeling generally unwell.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies any new joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.
• Neurological: Reports headaches.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with Lisinopril.
Diabetes: Controlled with Metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure 122/70, heart rate 67, temperature 98.4°F.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.
• Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
• Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Possible Lyme disease:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with a tick bite and a bull's-eye rash, which raises concern for Lyme disease.
   • Additional Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm the diagnosis.
   • Medical Treatment: Initiate Doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled with Lisinopril.
   • Additional Testing: Order a lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg once a day.

3. Diabetes:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood sugars are running in the 120s, indicating good control with Metformin.
   • Additional Testing: Order a Hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control and a basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice a day.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
